I believe this guidance is lacking in research-intensive institutions. Many higher education (e.g., the U15) do not do a very good job of research data management because of the following reasons:
- No integrated tools exist.
- Institutional guidelines are not enforced.
- Most researchers 'do their own thing'.
- Many researchers are dependent on their teams to apply disciplined research data management hygiene.
- Many Research Ethics Boards (REBs) only engage 'for cause' and little proactive monitoring is performed.
- There is little automated support for agreement management. (e.g., Team NDAs, Collaborator Data-Sharing Agreements, and Participant Consent Forms)
- Engagement with internal IT teams to deliver data storage and/or tools is cumbersome - especially for distributed teams.

We believe DRA should partner with and commission relevant providers that can quickly deliver these kinds of platforms.
column81: We believe DRA should collaborate with us to commission the next-generation research data management platform for Canada. We have brought this idea forward to DRA and have demonstrated our ability to apply new emerging technology (blockchain) to effectively secure sensitive research data sharing.
column82:
Grants from DRA could fund the further development of features on our platform that all universities would benefit from. 

We believe a platform that could do the following provides a compelling leap forward for most research-intensive institutions:

- Fast research project initiation
- Simplified RLS engagement & support
- Integrated ARECCI Screening Tool and REB engagement & review
- Simplified team member, external collaborator, and research participant onboarding
- eSignature-enabled NDAs, Data-Sharing Agreements, and Consent Form management
- Data upload and sharing on CAC Data Center repository
- Granular data access control and management
- Tracking of all data management activities within a research project
- Realtime reporting and analytics
- Ability to transfer research data or subsets of data
- "Stealth project" capability
- Alerts and notifications for data archiving, retention, and deletion
- Virtual data room capabilities
- Advanced research computing
- Distributed peer reviews
- Ability to securely share and publish research data
- Ability to commercialize research data 

We believe that with some grant funding and in collaboration with DRA, this type of capability can be quickly and readily realized.
column83:
Very few existing research software platforms go beyond data storage with some limited search capabilities and tools.

Almost none deliver the following:
- Support for operational control of research data as described above.
- Support for stakeholder engagement as described above. (e.g., team members, external collaborators, and research participants)
- Support for data management after research conclusion (e.g., archiving, retention, and deletion)
- Ability to seamlessly publish research data.
- Ability to securely share research data using state-of-the-art encryption or web3 protocols.
- Ability to subscribe to published research.

My comprehension of "research software": research (adjective) software (noun), therefore its definition should include the things that lives digitally and must exclude the aforementioned hardware, and people.

My comprehension of "software research": software (adjective) research (noun), in this case, it is the research itself and it should include the people, the activities, etc.

It makes sense to me to show a file, a process, or even a concept and tell that this is a research software, or this is part of a research software.
But it does not make sense to point at a disk, a cable or a person and tell that this is part of a research software. Software and hardware are concepts that were defined in opposition and to include one into the other would only cause confusion to an external observer.

column82: My field has been significantly hindered by the lack of long-term funding for software developer/maintainer positions. There is a strong interest from the research community for common software tools, but very limited capability to develop them -- there are very limited funding opportunities to support hiring developers, and the funding that is available is almost always short/fixed term. The project I'm part of now is funded by a 5-year CFI grant: we've been able to develop many useful and popular tools, but have very limited ability to maintain them beyond the grant lifespan; we've also struggled a lot with staff retention. Since the grant is explicitly fixed term, developers and support staff are incentivized to "jump ship" to newer or longer term positions as soon as possible. Having some ability to create permanent positions would vastly improve development efficiency: software could be supported for longer, could be further developed to have more features and capabilities, more packages could be developed, and the loss of subject matter expertise could be significantly reduced.
column83: I think there's a gap in the form of career paths for subject-matter experts who develop research software. Research software needs a combination of software experts (those trained as developers) and subject-matter experts (those trained in the specific research area and also have basic/intermediate development skills). Software experts have a career path through industry, but subject-matter experts only career path is through pure/traditional academia which doesn't reward development work. Thus subject-matter experts are not rewarded for doing software work or development the skills to contribute to software work. We need a dedicated career path for trained academics to pursue research-related software development -- effectively permanent postdoc positions with explicit focus on software development and maintenance for the larger research community.

HW, SW and research methods evolve very rapidly - a LOT of SW really may not be worth reusing after a given project is done or when the world has moved on from that way of approaching a problem or that technology (DOS to windows to linux, CPUs to GPUs, old algorithms to ML/DL,  running on laptops to running on cloud,  servers to VMs to Kubernetes etc)  .   Only domain experts can make make the distinction.  This is not to say that no SW can be re-used - but it's not liking reusing tin cans which can be melted down and turned into something completely different.

column374: Preserving is fine for historical-type reasons (somebody might want to study how coding techniques have evolved etc)  but likely not very valuable for RS.   Research problems of the future (i.e. 5 yrs from now)  will have scale, complexity, techniques, new HW, new SW, new languages, greater compute power which will make that old SW pointless.     It's like saying that we should preserve our old computers - PETs, TRS-80s, Vax  etc - because somebody might want to reuse them.... Maybe somebody wants to browse the web with mosaic? Or run FORTRAN66. But should we spend research $ supporting that when there are far faster easier and more efficient ways now?

column70: In the end, this definition seems off. Software is software. If it doesn't have code, it isn't software. There are a lot of peripheral things, but research software is about code that does research, and/or is used by researchers to do (possibly in a guidance or interpretative way) research.
column80:
I wish there were decent research software training provided. I feel like 95% of the Alliance-sponsored courses are things that could be readily found online, and the Alliance has an alarming tendency to replace online content with webinars/courses. There are a lot of things where the documentation of online tools/procedures on Alliance resources could be documented (and the documentation maintained) *much* better. 

I feel like most "generic" software training should be done using widely available online resources; what would be more useful are the small-scale hands-on mentorships where someone goes from knowing how to code, use HPC, etc. to knowing how to *really* code (software design, critical thinking, best practices, etc.). I feel like most of the online training provided by the Alliance is of the type that ChatGPT can replace.
column81: It would be great to have funding to support people to help our packages develop. The "Software Infrastructure for Scientific Innovation" grants in the USA, for example, fund both graduate/postdoctoral fellowships (in house), visits of graduate/postdoctoral fellows to central institutes (combination of in house and on site), and central institutes that are supposed to (but this seems to be the weakest point) provide infrastructure (non-research, but common utilities) and training that is less at the bleeding edge. A model like this, where there is centralized development/expertise on common problems, but most funding goes to support in-house training and experts, seems to work well. I am less enthusiastic about pay-for-service:  it is *research* software and I feel like the hiring that goes into it shold support development of HQP. For larger projects, a long-time-horizon full-time staff person or two might be justifiable, though.

column88: Several of the QC-Devs packages could be widely used, but they are free, open-source, and (basically) easy to install. I think anyone with some basic competence at Python could use them, and people who can program (or at least script) are our target audience. column89:
I worry that the Alliance is going to fall into the trap of trying to support existing players in the ecosystem, instead of looking at what new types of things are emerging. I remember going to a Canarie software conference and realizing that a lot of the people there didn't seem to actually know much about software, and were basically maintaining/enhancing old-fashioned software infrastructure. The newer free-and-open-source communities, software best practices (documentation, modularity, testing, etc.) were underrepresented. Basically, the Alliance has an obligation to support existing efforts (if they are facillitating high-quality research), but also to be open to emerging patterns and new teams, which did not fit in the comfort zone of Canarie. 

I am a fan of the software infrastructure for scientific innovation style in the USA, but I realize that probably Canada, being Canada, will not invest enough money to make it work. (In my discipline of theoretical chemistry, basically *every* research group has 75-150k$/year of funding from an SISI grant. This is a great thing (it ensures that their research is distributed as free and open-source software, rather than just dying the moment it is published).)
